title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not identify a body of water invaded by Asian carp that is labeled on the map, such as any of the following:

  • Mississippi River

  • Lake Erie

  • Missouri River

  • Ohio River

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe the change in the distribution of Asian carp since their introduction in the 1970s, such as any of the following:

  • They are more widely distributed/found in most of the watershed/in a larger area than they were in the 1970s

  • They have moved up/down the Mississippi river

  • They have moved up the Missouri River/Ohio River

  • They have moved northwest and northeast up the rivers

The response describes the change in the distribution of Asian carp since their introduction in the 1970s, such as one of the following:

  • They are more widely distributed/found in most of the watershed/in a larger area than they were in the 1970s

  • They have moved up/down the Mississippi river

  • They have moved up the Missouri River/Ohio River

  • They have moved northwest and northeast up the rivers

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one impact the introduction of Asian carp could have on the ecosystem services provided by the Great Lakes region, such as any of the following:

  • Improved drinking water quality as carp consume algae

  • Decreased recreational opportunities (boating/swimming) from the increased population of carp in the water interfering with activities

  • Decreased fishing due to carp outcompeting native fish species

  • Decreased drinking water quality as carp displace filter feeders like native mussels in the food chain/web

  • Decreased algae population resulting in decreased photosynthesis and increased greenhouse gases/global warming/climate change

  • Decreased algae population resulting in decreased photosynthesis and decreased oxygen production

The response describes one impact the introduction of Asian carp could have on the ecosystem services provided by the Great Lakes region, such as one of the following:

  • Improved drinking water quality as carp consume algae

  • Decreased recreational opportunities (boating/swimming) from the increased population of carp in the water interfering with activities

  • Decreased fishing due to carp outcompeting native fish species

  • Decreased drinking water quality as carp displace filter feeders like native mussels in the food chain/web

  • Decreased algae population resulting in decreased photosynthesis and increased greenhouse gases/global warming/climate change

  • Decreased algae population resulting in decreased photosynthesis and decreased oxygen production

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not propose a realistic solution to help reduce the spread of the Asian carp from their current distribution, such as any of the following:

  • Offer incentives for fishers to catch and kill carp

  • Encourage consumption of carp

  • Build fencing/netting between waterways

  • Use shock treatment (dispersal barrier system)

  • Create/Use an Asian-carp specific poison/deterrent (carpicide, CO 2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHXgarmWu51MyVXgarqqtubsr4rNCHbcvPDwzYbGeaGqiFv0Je9sqqrpepiYdbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=xfr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaaeaabaWaaaGcbaGaae4qaiaab+eadaWgaaWcbaGaaeOmaaqabaaaaa@3287@ , microparticles)

  • Implement high-frequency sound deterrent system

  • Prohibit transfer of bait or ballast water from one body of water to another

  • Offer incentives for fishers to catch and kill carp

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify zooplankton as the primary consumer in the Great Lakes food chain.
The response identifies zooplankton as the primary consumer in the Great Lakes food chain.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one possible effect of the introduction of the Asian carp on the Great Lakes food chain, such as any of the following:

  • There will be fewer zooplankton/macroinvertebrates/yellow perch/rainbow trout

  • There will be less food for other species at the same trophic level on the food chain

  • There will be less food for species that don’t eat carp and are higher on the food chain

title: Part I
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one way that overfishing of blue pike illustrates the tragedy of the commons, such as any of the following:

  • The blue pike are a shared resource that were depleted/went extinct due to unregulated access

  • The blue pike are a common resource that were depleted by fishers, maximizing profits/catching as many as possible

The response describes one way that overfishing of blue pike illustrates the tragedy of the commons, such as one of the following:

  • The blue pike are a shared resource that were depleted/went extinct due to unregulated access

  • The blue pike are a common resource that were depleted by fishers, maximizing profits/catching as many as possible

title: Part J
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one disadvantage of using aquaculture to reduce overfishing, such as any of the following:

  • Aquaculture contaminates water with excess organic waste/antibiotics

  • Fish that escape from facilities compete or breed with wild fish

  • Fish in aquaculture facilities can spread diseases to wild fish

  • The high density of fish in aquaculture facilities can lead to increased disease

  • Loss of jobs in the fishing industry

  • Excess pressure on fisheries/wild stocks used to create food pellets

  • Decrease in genetic diversity of farm raised/aquaculture fish

  • Habitat degradation from conversion of ecosystems to fish farms

  • Overuse of antibiotics in farmed fish (create antibiotic resistant bacteria that can be harmful to humans)

  • Aquaculture contaminates water with excess organic waste/antibiotics

  • Fish that escape from facilities compete or breed with wild fish
